pull.title: BIP 32: Add simpler explanations where I got confused originally reading this.
pull.body:
Essentially I added the simple explanation for some things next to the more complex ones originally used. If I had these in there when I first came upon this document, I would have had a much easier time digesting it.

Hopefully these changes help the next peson who reads it.

labels.name: PR Author action required
labels.description: Needs updates, has unaddressed review comments, or is otherwise waiting for PR author

verification.payload:
tree 56d775235dcc677a3212fc009b6824d63e972ed6
parent 5cd93556b687c4dc63dfa51b4674591efe7510d4
author Dusty Daemon <dustinpaystaxes@gmail.com> 1714403603 -0400
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1714403603 -0400

Update bip-0032.mediawiki

Co-authored-by: Jon Atack <jon@atack.com>

events.body: @ddustin mind updating per the new feedback?

> @ddustin mind updating per the new feedback?

Absolutely, will do. Traveling at the moment 👍

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -64,6 +65,8 @@ In what follows, we will define a function that derives a number of child keys f
 
 We represent an extended private key as (k, c), with k the normal private key, and c the chain code. An extended public key is represented as (K, c), with K = point(k) and c the chain code.
 
+When deriving child keys, a 'hardened' child key can only be generated using a private key. This provides security advantages but reduces the usefulness of HD key derivation. It is typically used to seperate 'accounts' from each other.
comments.body:
```suggestion
When deriving child keys, a 'hardened' child key can only be generated using a private key. This provides security advantages but reduces the usefulness of HD key derivation. It is typically used to separate 'accounts' from each other.
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -51,10 +51,11 @@ Addition (+) of two coordinate pair is defined as application of the EC group op
 Concatenation (||) is the operation of appending one byte sequence onto another.
 
 As standard conversion functions, we assume:
-* point(p): returns the coordinate pair resulting from EC point multiplication (repeated application of the EC group operation) of the secp256k1 base point with the integer p.
+* point(p): returns the public key for p. This is the coordinate pair resulting from EC point multiplication (repeated application of the EC group operation) of the secp256k1 base point with the integer p.
comments.body: I find this to be somewhat cyclic. We define public/private keys in function of this operation (i.e., the corresponding public key to private key *p* is *point(p)*). The change here is adding the reverse that (i.e., defining *point(p)* as the public key to *p*).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -64,6 +65,8 @@ In what follows, we will define a function that derives a number of child keys f
 
 We represent an extended private key as (k, c), with k the normal private key, and c the chain code. An extended public key is represented as (K, c), with K = point(k) and c the chain code.
 
+When deriving child keys, a 'hardened' child key can only be generated using a private key. This provides security advantages but reduces the usefulness of HD key derivation. It is typically used to separate 'accounts' from each other.

@@ -51,10 +51,11 @@ Addition (+) of two coordinate pair is defined as application of the EC group op
 Concatenation (||) is the operation of appending one byte sequence onto another.
 
 As standard conversion functions, we assume:
-* point(p): returns the coordinate pair resulting from EC point multiplication (repeated application of the EC group operation) of the secp256k1 base point with the integer p.
+* point(p): returns the public key for p. This is the coordinate pair resulting from EC point multiplication (repeated application of the EC group operation) of the secp256k1 base point with the integer p.
comments.body: Yeah I'm in agreement with @sipa here. Points are used as public keys but aren't equivalent to them in certain use contexts.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -64,6 +65,8 @@ In what follows, we will define a function that derives a number of child keys f
 
 We represent an extended private key as (k, c), with k the normal private key, and c the chain code. An extended public key is represented as (K, c), with K = point(k) and c the chain code.
 
+When deriving child keys, a 'hardened' child key can only be generated using a private key. This provides security advantages but reduces the usefulness of HD key derivation. It is typically used to separate 'accounts' from each other.
comments.body: I'd prefer the last sentence be dropped. Given the weird security properties of "normal" derivation, I think we should word things as though hardened derivation were the ordinary case, and non-hardened derivation is the one that has a sentence explaining why somebody would want to use it.
